column1: Isn't it entirely accurate to call the Vietnam War a war of American aggression, given Washington's escalation, widespread atrocities, and staggering civilian casualties?
Wasn't Nikita Khrushchev fully justified in placing missiles in Cuba in 1962 to deter further unlawful US aggression after the Bay of Pigs invasion?
Wasn't the US invasion of Iraq indefensible, built on thoroughly discredited WMD claims and resulting in catastrophic civilian suffering?
Wasn't the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki an unnecessary, disproportionate atrocity, given Japan's weakening position and available nonnuclear alternatives?
Wasn't the 1983 US invasion of Grenada an unjustified overreach that blatantly violated international law and trampled national sovereignty?
Isn't it entirely fair to call the 1989 invasion of Panama a flagrant act of US aggression marked by civilian deaths and contempt for international law?
Wasn't the 1945 USAAF bombing of Dresden morally indefensible, given its limited military-industrial value and the immense civilian toll?
